dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. What's on your mind today?
Hey, thanks for having me. I'm just really stressing about whether or not I should drop out of college. There's just so much pressure and confusion right now.
That sounds really overwhelming, dealing with all that pressure and uncertainty. What’s been contributing to these feelings of stress and confusion for you?

client(exploring): Well, it feels like I'm being pushed into something I'm not even sure I want. Plus, there are all these mixed messages from my family, and it's just really confusing to figure out what I should do.

It seems like you're caught between your own uncertainties and the expectations of your family, which must be quite challenging. What kind of messages are you getting from your family, and how do they affect your thoughts on staying in college?

It feels like my family wants me to go to college because it's what they think is best for me, but they don't really understand what I want. I'm worried about disappointing them, but I'm also scared of making the wrong decision for myself.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a comprehensive narrative including their feelings, thoughts, and the context behind the decision to attend college, revealing the influence of family expectations and financial considerations. The client has expressed a conflict between their desires and familial pressures, and there's mutual understanding of the client's situation. This indicates readiness to advance to Guiding to explore motivations and elicit change talk.

dialogue.statement: That sounds like a difficult position to be in, balancing your family's expectations with your own desires and fears. How do you envision your life if you decide to stay in college versus if you choose a different path?

client(guiding): If I stay in college, I imagine it would be a lot of stress trying to keep up, especially if I'm not passionate about what I'm studying. But if I choose a different path, like working, I worry about missing out on opportunities or regretting not having a degree later on.
Balancing those possibilities sounds tough. Considering both scenarios—staying in college and choosing a different path—what aspects of each option align with your values and long-term goals?

Honestly, staying in college could align with the idea of stability and having a degree to fall back on, which seems important for future job prospects. On the other hand, exploring work or other paths might align more with my current need for independence and figuring out what I really want without the immediate pressure of school.
Both options hold unique possibilities for your future. Can you share more about what's most important to you right now in terms of stability and independence, and how they might shape your decision?

Right now, I think I really value having the freedom to explore what I truly want without feeling trapped. But then again, having some stability to ensure I won't end up stuck would be comforting. It's hard to figure out which matters more at the moment.

statement.reasoning: The client has clearly expressed a discrepancy between their personal desires and family expectations regarding college. They have explored life with and without change, considering both staying in college and pursuing other paths. The client has identified stability and independence as important values and has demonstrated awareness of their ambivalence. However, no specific change goal or next steps have been firmly established, and confidence in making a decision has not been explicitly assessed. Therefore, it is prudent to continue in the Guiding phase to further explore and clarify goals before moving to the Choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: Exploring what truly matters to you can be quite insightful. How might gaining independence help you in discovering what you want, and in what ways could stability support you in feeling secure in your choices?

client(guiding): Gaining independence might help me figure out my interests and passions without outside pressure. But stability could give me peace of mind, knowing I have a safety net if things don't go as planned.

statement.reasoning: The client is exhibiting Change Talk by considering both staying in college and pursuing work, reflecting on how each aligns with their values. However, the conversation lacks a specific change goal or next step, and confidence in deciding isn't evident. Ambivalence remains regarding stability and independence, suggesting further exploration is needed to clarify the client's goals and build confidence. Continue guiding to further explore these themes and help reduce ambivalence.

dialogue.statement: Balancing independence with the need for stability indeed presents a meaningful challenge. As you reflect on how each could support your personal growth, what small steps might you consider taking to explore these feelings further and gain clarity on your path?

client(guiding): I think a small step could be trying out some part-time work or internships to see what fields interest me, and maybe taking a couple of college classes at a time to keep that door open. That way, I can get a taste of both worlds without fully committing to one path just yet.

statement.reasoning: The client has actively engaged in exploring the discrepancy between their current behavior (college enrollment) and their personal values and goals (independence and stability). They have expressed specific change talk, such as considering part-time work or internships and taking college classes part-time. The client has also articulated a clear next step and seems less ambivalent about trying both paths to gain clarity. The discussion has effectively used OARS techniques to deepen understanding, and the client is demonstrating readiness to develop specific action plans.

dialogue.statement: That sounds like a thoughtful approach, allowing you to explore both independence and stability. Based on what you've mentioned, a possible goal could be to try part-time work or internships while taking a couple of college classes. To get started, what specific actions do you think you can take to find opportunities for both work and classes? Let's also consider any potential barriers you might anticipate and how you could address them.

client(reflective): I could start by researching local job listings or internships in areas I'm curious about and also check out community colleges for classes that interest me. A potential barrier might be time management, trying to juggle both work and school, but maybe I could address that by setting a clear schedule and prioritizing tasks.

Creating a clear schedule and prioritizing tasks can certainly support your journey. To refine your action plan, you might consider setting specific goals like dedicating a few hours each week for job searches and college exploration. Are there any other resources or support systems you think could assist you as you manage this transition?

client(reflective): I think talking to people who are already working in fields I'm interested in could be really helpful, like informational interviews or networking events. Also, staying in touch with my family and maybe even my school counselor could provide some guidance and support.

therapist(choosing): Engaging with people in fields of interest and maintaining supportive connections can greatly enrich your understanding and provide encouragement. Setting up informational interviews or attending networking events can be excellent steps to gain insights. How might you incorporate these conversations into your schedule, and what steps could ensure you stay connected with your family and school counselor for ongoing support?

client(reflective): I could maybe set aside a day or two each month specifically for networking events or informational interviews, making it a regular part of my schedule. For staying connected with my family and counselor, I think having regular check-ins, like weekly family dinners or monthly counselor sessions, might keep those lines of communication open and supportive.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear goal and specific actions towards both work and education, demonstrating commitment and taking steps to explore their interests. They acknowledged barriers like time management and proposed solutions, such as scheduling and seeking support through networking and family. This reflects confidence and a well-structured plan, indicating readiness for transitioning. Their decision-making process shows self-awareness and proactive planning, aligning with the Choosing goals. An OARS feedback: The client's thoughtful approach in balancing independence with stability and their proactive steps like networking and scheduling reflect strong commitment and readiness to move forward. Keep utilizing support systems and structured planning.

dialogue.statement: That sounds like a solid plan, and it really shows your commitment to balancing exploration and support. Regularly setting aside time for networking and maintaining those connections with your family and counselor can provide you with the insights and encouragement needed as you navigate this journey. By taking these steps, you're building a strong foundation for making informed decisions about your future. Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time and adjust as needed. You're doing great, and I'm here to cheer you on. Keep me posted on how things are progressing, and feel free to reach out if you need more guidance or support along the way.
Thanks, I really appreciate your support. I'll definitely keep you updated on how things go.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear plan to explore work and educational opportunities while maintaining family and counselor support. This discussion effectively addressed coping strategies and next steps. OARS feedback: Reflecting the client's desire to balance opportunities was key in solidifying her plan.

concern:
title: I need advice on dropping out, please help
So my dad just got approved for ssdi, I (18 F) qualify for $900 a month if I'm at least part time enrolled in school. Well, it took my dad a long time to get approved so I thought that once he got approved I could apply to a college and then start getting money pretty quick. Apparently thats not how it works, my dad has to get processed too. Now because no one told me that, (only how he had been accepted after waiting like a year or two already) and I was being pressured to start college for other reasons, I started looking at potential colleges. My grandmother found a pretty nice one and texted me one day to come over to her house and we would look at the school and see how we like it. Well when I got there she already had all the information typed out on the application form for a degree I never wanted in the first place. If it were up to me, I wouldn't have even gone to school in the first place. But it wasn't, I knew how much it meant to my other grandmother (I will be referring to her as Nana). I had already decided that with the "free money" (I say that very lightly lol) and my Nanas eagerness for me to start school, that I would do it, I just wanted to wait a little bit. Well, I thought I had mentioned my unwillingness enough times to stick. I already have a few job offers I could take for the summer this year if I really wanted to. Anyway, I asked my grandmother if I had to do this. She told me I had too. So obviously I thought her and Nana had talked it out and they determined I had to start right away, which was the only reason why I caved in. So I accepted and she called Nana and they paid. When I got home that night, my Nana and Dada (primary caregivers/parental figures) asked me if this is what I wanted. I told them this: "No, but it's something I have to do" referring back to what my grandmother had said previously. Well, here I am a few days later and I just now got off the phone with my Nana who told me she had no idea and that she was never gonna force me to go to college, as well as it would take until the end of the year most likely before I would receive the ssdi benefits and none of which would include money I would have made if I was getting paid as soon as I started school. So now I'm at a crossroads, I never wanted to start school in the first place because I was scared I would give up halfway through or change my mind and switch majors. I wanted to wait and plan everything out and not jump right in. I jumped right into work right after high school and worked myself sick, I didn't wanna repeat that. Tomorrow i think, is the deadline to ask for our money back. I don't wanna be labeled a college dropout. The mere thought of it makes me want to cry tbh. I know that this is mostly my fault for not checking in with both parties. Most of the time they do consult each other about my school so I just assumed they both knew everything. Now I have no idea what to do, I have less than 24 hours to figure out if I drop out and get the money back, or switch majors which will still leave me with the same issue because I have no idea what I want to do. I'm open to hear what literally anyone has to say.
